name: Aire Crossing
description: Aire Crossing is a quiet, remote spot to camp. Just north of this campground is the stunning Triplet Falls.
Camping at Aire Crossing is free and on a first in, first served basis.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.
It has toilets and 5 campsites.

name: Sharps Camping Area
description: Sharps Camping Area is close to walks.
It has 8 campsites and is suitable for camp trailers. There are no toilets.
Camping here is free and is on a first in, first served basis.
Be self sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.

name: Cora Lynn
description: There are two tranquil campsites at Cora Lyn. Access is by foot via the track leading from the Blanket Leaf picnic area.
Camping is free and on a first come, first served basis.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.

name: Wye River Road Camping Area
description: Wye River Road Camping area is near the township of Wye River. The camping area is about 2km inland on the Wye River Road.
There are 12 campsites and the camping area can be accessed by camp trailers. There are no toilets.
Camping is free and on a first in, first served basis.
Be self sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.

name: Hammond Road Campground
description: The Hammonds Road Campground has plenty of space and is suitable for tents and caravans.
It has 20 campsites and a toilet.
Camping here is free and on a first come, first served basis.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.

name: Big Hill Camping Area
description: Big Hill is an open, easily accessible camping area with 20 campsites suitable for tents or caravans.
Camping is free and on a first in, first served basis.
There is a toilet.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.

name: Lake Elizabeth
description: Head to Lake Elizabeth hidden deep in the Otways near the township of Forrest. Discover its inspiring beauty with heavily timbered flanks and calm waters punctuated by the trunks of dead trees, drowned when the valley was flooded more than 50 years ago to form this "perched lake" .
The elusive platypus can be found in the waters of the lake - wake up early or head to Lake Elizabeth at dusk to catch a glimpse of these shy Australian natives.

There are 15 sheltered campsites on the river, close to the lake. The access track is unsuitable for cars towing caravans. This is a walk-in camping area, approximately 80 to 100 metres from the parking area.
Camping is free and on a first come, first served basis.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.

name: Aire River (West)
description: Aire River (West) is a big, flat and open camping area on the western side of the Aire River.
It's a good place for large groups to camp. It has 50 grassy campsites suitable for tents and caravans.
Camping here is free of charge and on a first in, first served basis.
There are toilets and fireplaces provided.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.
Enjoy fishing and canoeing on the river. There is a boat ramp nearby.

Discover the peaceful estuarine waters of Aire River, Hordenvale Wetlands and the impressive view from the Escarpment lookout over the ocean and wetlands. Keep an eye out for kangaroos and wallabies in the coastal scrub.

name: Allenvale
description: The old Allenvale Mile site is just beyond the outskirts of Lorne. This is a walk in camping area, although it's only a short walk to the campground (around 200 metres).
There are 20 camping sites and toilets.
Camping here is free and on a first in, first served basis.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.

name: Parker Hill
description: There is a small campground at Parker Hill with 8 campsites and toilets.
Camping is free and on a first come, first served basis.
Be self sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.
Parker Inlet is a great location to explore geology and wildlife. There is no bridge at Parker Inlet, so carefully assess before wading across.

name: Aire River (East)
description: Aire River (East) is a shady, small spot to camp. It is about half the size of the camping area on the other side of the river (Aire River West).
This is a great place for kayaking. The best place to launch is near the bridge at the Aire River campsites.
Aire River (East) has 20 grassy campsites, toilets and a boat ramp.
Camping here is free of charge and is on a first in, first served basis.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.
There are no fireplaces at Aire River East. Bring a portable fuel stoves or gas barbecue.

Discover the peaceful estuarine waters of Aire River, Hordenvale Wetlands and the impressive view from the Escarpment lookout over the ocean and wetlands. Keep an eye out for kangaroos and wallabies in the coastal scrub.

name: Blanket Bay
description: During the Summer and Easter holiday periods Blanket Bay campsites are allocated by ballot. Outside of this period the campground is available on a first-in first-served basis.
Along with the car-based camping area at Blanket Bay, there are also purpose-built Great Ocean Walk hike-in and group camping areas.

The hike-in campsite has eight individual camp pads set into the surrounding bushland. Each camp pad has room for a 2-3 person tent. There is a maximum number of 12 people per hiker party, booking no more than four hike-in campsites at each location.
The group camping area offers larger and more open sites catering for groups up to16 people with enough room for eight 2-3 person tents.
Registration fees apply at these campsites and hikers must book at least two weeks in advance.

name: Johanna Beach
description: Nestled among the sand dunes, Johanna Beach is a good spot for camping with dogs, caravaning, picknicking and walking. Surfing is also popular here.
There are 50 grassy campsites at Johanna Beach. There are also toilets.
Camping is free and on a first come, first served basis.
Be self-sufficient with drinking water as there is none provided.
